hints_html:
Recall that the Fourier coefficients of a sine series of a function \(f(x)\) are given by,

\[\begin{aligned} b_n=\frac{2}{L}\int_0^Lf(x)\sin\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right)\end{aligned}\]

and the coefficients of a cosine series in the form

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{a_0}{2}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty{}a_n\cos\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right)\end{aligned}\]

are given by

\[\begin{aligned} a_n=\frac{2}{L}\int_0^Lf(x)\cos\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right).\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
Recall that the Fourier coefficients of a sine series of a function <math>f(x)</math> are given by,

:<math>
b_n=\frac{2}{L}\int_0^Lf(x)\sin\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right)
</math>

and the coefficients of a cosine series in the form

:<math>
\frac{a_0}{2}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty{}a_n\cos\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right)
</math>

are given by

:<math>
a_n=\frac{2}{L}\int_0^Lf(x)\cos\left(\frac{n\pi{x}}{L}\right).
</math>
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
We will start by computing the Fourier sine series. The Fourier sine series of \(f(x)\) is given by

\(Sf(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty b_n \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L})\)
where
\(b_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_0^L f(x) \; \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \; dx \;\;\)
for \(n = {\color{blue}1},2,3,\cdots\)

Here, we have \(f(x) = x\) and \(L = 1\). So

\[\begin{aligned} b_n = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \sin(n \pi x) \; dx .\end{aligned}\]

Integrate by parts using

\[\begin{aligned} u = x \;\;\;\;\;\; dv = \sin(n \pi x) \; dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} du = dv \;\;\;\; v = \frac{-1}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x) ,\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} b_n &= 2 [\frac{-x}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x)|_0^1 + \frac{1}{n \pi} \int_0^1 \cos(n \pi x) \; dx ]\\ &= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{-x}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x)|_0^1} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(n \pi x) |_0^1} ]\\&= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{-1}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi) + 0} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(n \pi) - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(0) } ] .\end{aligned}\]

Since \({\color{Brown} \sin(n \pi) = 0 }\) and\({\color{Brown} \sin(0) = 0 }\), we get that

\[\begin{aligned} b_n = \frac{-2}{n \pi} \underbrace{\cos(n \pi)}_{=(-1)^n} = \frac{-2}{n \pi} (-1)^n = \frac{2}{n \pi} (-1)^{n+1} \;\;\end{aligned}\]


for \(n = 1,2,3,\cdots\)
Therefore, the Fourier sine series of \(f(x)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} Sf(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty b_n \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) = \sum_{n =1}^\infty \frac{2}{n \pi} (-1)^{n+1} \sin(n \pi x) .\end{aligned}\]

Next, we will find the Fourier cosine series. The Fourier cosine series of \(f(x)\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} Cf(x) = \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n \cos(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \;\;\end{aligned}\]


where
\(a_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_0^L f(x) \; \cos(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \; dx \;\;\)
for \(n = {\color{blue}0},1,2,\cdots\)

With \(f(x) = x\) and \(L = 1\),

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \cos(n \pi x) \; dx .\end{aligned}\]

When \(n=0\) we have that \(\cos(n\pi{x})\)=1 and so we have two distinct cases for evaluating the integral; when \(n>=1\) and when \(n=0\). For the case where \({\color{red} n \geq 1}\), integrate by parts using

\[\begin{aligned} u = x \;\;\;\;\;\; dv = \cos(n \pi x) \; dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} du = dv \;\;\;\; v = \frac{1}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x) ,\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} a_n &= 2 [\frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x)|_0^1 - \frac{1}{n \pi} \int_0^1 \sin(n \pi x) \; dx ] \\ &= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x)|_0^1} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(n \pi x) |_0^1} ] \\&= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi) + 0} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(n \pi) - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(0) } ].\end{aligned}\]

Since \({\color{blue} \sin(n \pi) = 0}\), we get that

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = 2 [ (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \underbrace{\cos(n \pi)}_{=(-1)^n} - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \underbrace{\cos(0)}_{=1} ] = 2 (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 [(-1)^n - 1]\;\;\end{aligned}\]


for \(n = {\color{red}1},2,3,\cdots\)

Now for the case where \({ \color{red} n = 0}\), we get

\[\begin{aligned} a_0 = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \cos(0) dx = 2 \int_0^1 x dx = 2 (\frac{1}{2} x^2)|_0^1 = 1.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, the Fourier cosine series of \(f(x)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} Cf(x) = \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n \cos(n \pi x) = \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty 2 (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 [ (-1)^n - 1] \cos(n \pi x) .\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We will start by computing the Fourier sine series. The Fourier sine series of <math> f(x) </math> is given by 
:
<br />
<math> 
Sf(x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  b_n \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L})
</math>
<br />
where
<br />
<math>
b_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_0^L f(x) \; \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \; dx \;\; 
</math>
<br />
for <math>n = {\color{blue} 1},2,3,\cdots </math>

Here, we have <math> f(x) = x </math> and <math> L = 1 </math>. So
:<math> b_n = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \sin(n \pi x) \; dx . </math>
Integrate by parts using
:<math> u = x  \;\;\;\;\;\; dv = \sin(n \pi x) \; dx  </math>
:<math> du = dv \;\;\;\; v = \frac{-1}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x) ,</math>
we get that
:<math> 
\begin{align}
b_n &= 2 [\frac{-x}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x)|_0^1 + \frac{1}{n \pi} \int_0^1 \cos(n \pi x) \; dx ]\\
&= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{-x}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi x)|_0^1} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(n \pi x) |_0^1} ]\\
& = 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{-1}{n \pi} \cos(n \pi) + 0} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(n \pi) - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \sin(0) } ] .
\end{align}
</math>
Since <math> {\color{Brown} \sin(n \pi) = 0 } </math> and <math> {\color{Brown} \sin(0) = 0 } </math>, we get that
:<math> b_n = \frac{-2}{n \pi} \underbrace{\cos(n \pi)}_{=(-1)^n} = \frac{-2}{n \pi} (-1)^n = \frac{2}{n \pi} (-1)^{n+1} \;\;</math>
<br />
for <math>n = 1,2,3,\cdots </math>
<br />
Therefore, the Fourier sine series of <math> f(x) </math> is
:<math> Sf(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty b_n \sin(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) = \sum_{n =1}^\infty \frac{2}{n \pi} (-1)^{n+1} \sin(n \pi x) .</math>


Next, we will find the Fourier cosine series. The Fourier cosine series of <math> f(x) </math> is given by 
:<math> 
Cf(x) = \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty  a_n \cos(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \;\; 
</math>
<br />
where
<br />
<math>
a_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_0^L f(x) \; \cos(\frac{n \pi x}{L}) \; dx \;\;
</math> 
<br />
for <math>n = {\color{blue} 0},1,2,\cdots </math>

With <math> f(x) = x </math> and <math> L = 1 </math>,
:<math> a_n = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \cos(n \pi x) \; dx . </math>
When <math>n=0</math> we have that <math>\cos(n\pi{x})</math>=1 and so we have two distinct cases for evaluating the integral; when <math>n>=1</math> and when <math>n=0</math>.  For the case where <math> {\color{red} n \geq 1 } </math>, integrate by parts using
:<math> u = x  \;\;\;\;\;\; dv = \cos(n \pi x) \; dx  </math>
:<math> du = dv \;\;\;\; v = \frac{1}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x) ,</math>
we get that
<br />
<math>
\begin{align}
a_n &= 2 [\frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x)|_0^1 - \frac{1}{n \pi} \int_0^1 \sin(n \pi x) \; dx ] \\
& = 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi x)|_0^1} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(n \pi x) |_0^1} ] \\
&= 2 [{\color{blue} \frac{x}{n \pi} \sin(n \pi) + 0} + {\color{Brown} (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(n \pi) - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \cos(0) } ].
\end{align} 
</math>
<br />
Since <math> {\color{blue} \sin(n \pi) = 0 } </math>, we get that
:<math> a_n = 2 [ (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \underbrace{\cos(n \pi)}_{=(-1)^n}  - (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 \underbrace{\cos(0)}_{=1} ] = 2 (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 [(-1)^n - 1]\;\;
</math>
<br />
for <math> n = {\color{red} 1},2,3,\cdots </math>

Now for the case where <math>{ \color{red} n = 0 } </math>, we get
:<math> a_0 = 2 \int_0^1 x \; \cos(0) dx = 2 \int_0^1 x dx = 2 (\frac{1}{2} x^2)|_0^1 = 1. </math>

Therefore, the Fourier cosine series of <math> f(x) </math> is
:<math> Cf(x) = \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty  a_n \cos(n \pi x)  = \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^\infty  2 (\frac{1}{n \pi})^2 [ (-1)^n - 1] \cos(n \pi x) . </math>
statement_html: (a) Find both the Fourier sine series and the Fourier cosine series of the function \(f(x) = x\) on the interval \([0,1]\).
statement_latex:
(a) Find both the Fourier sine series and the Fourier cosine series of
the function $f(x) = x$ on the interval $[0,1]$.
statement_raw:
(a) Find both the Fourier sine series and the Fourier cosine series of the function <math> f(x) = x  </math> on the interval
<math> [0,1] </math>.
